decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, samples of the facing materials to be utilised in the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any windows or rooflights at first floor level or above in the northern (flank) or southern (flank) elevations (including the two side facing windows within the rear first floor bay) shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no windows shall be inserted nor any other openings formed (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) at first floor level or above in the in the northern (flank) or southern (flank) elevations of the dwelling unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no additions or enlargements to any dwellinghouse(s) on the site (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers and to safeguard the health and longevity of trees worthy of retention, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no detached buildings (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers and to safeguard the health and longevity of trees worthy of retention, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The rating level of the noise determined by the cumulative sound emissions of the plant to which this permission relates shall be at least 5dBA lower than the existing background noise level at any given time of operation. The noise levels shall be measured or predicted 1m externally to any window at the nearest residential facade and the measurements and assessment shall be made according to BS 4142:2014.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any external lighting installed at the site shall be angled so as to prevent any spillage or glare beyond the site's boundaries.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with "Tree Sruvey, Arboricultural Impact Assessment, Tree Constraints Plan, Arboricultural Method Statement and Tree Protection Plan" authored by Advanced Tree Services and dated March 2020. The approved measures shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a landscaping scheme shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. It shall not be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of and visitors to the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No development shall take place (including any works of demolition) until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:i) How the proposed development will be built;ii) Hours of working (which shall be limited to 08.00 to 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 to 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays);iii) The procedure for loading/unloading materials;iv) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;v) The protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;vi) The protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; vii) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site and whether a banksman will be provided;viii) Temporary site access;ix) Signing system for works traffic;x) Whether site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads;xi) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site;xii) The storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;xiii) The potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;xiv) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;xv) The location of all ancillary site buildings;xvi) The means of enclosure of the site, its erection and maintenance;xvii) Wheel washing equipment;xviii) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors.xix) Meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used)xx) The method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phasesDeliveries/collections to and from the site shall use a route that is agreed with the highway authority and the agreed route shall be signed accordingly.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

In the event that contamination is found (at any time) that was not previously identified, development shall cease and the contamination reported in writing to the local planning authority as soon as is reasonably practicable. An assessment, remediation scheme and verification report shall then be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority before development resumes.Reason: To ensure that risks from land contamination are minimised, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a sustainable drainage strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan for surface water drainage at the site using SuDS methods shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved sustainable drainage strategy prior to the beneficial occupation of the development and permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The site comprises a mid-terrace dwelling.10 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment:  The proposed pitched roof addition to an existing flat roof rear extension, would not be visible from the streetscene and would also appear to be a subordinate addition to the host property.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties and the proposed pitched roof addition is to an existing flat roof rear extension, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of loss of privacy, overbearing appearance, or loss of light. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a detached dwelling.26 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 objection has been received relating to:- Excessive height or bulk of buildings;- Inappropriate design/layout;- Loss of light/sunlight;- Noise; and,- Privacy.Officers note that the proposal would be for residential use, and as such it is considered that there would be no material increase in noise on site. The remaining concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note that the current application is a revision of previously refused application ref: 21/02627/HOU. The principal issue with the refused application was the scale of the proposed first floor side extension and proximity on the shared boundary. The refused application would have resulted in a dominant and incongruous addition to the original dwelling, which would have eroded an existing gap between two properties on Manorgate Road. Whilst the proposed first floor side extension would not achieve total compliance with the Council's guidance, it would now be set in from the shared boundary by 1m and as such would ensure that the proposal appears visually subordinate to the host property, thereby addressing this issue.The proposal would raise the ridge of the existing roof slope, however, given the roof ridge is substantially lower than neighbouring properties, officers consider that the increase would not appear incongruous within the immediate vicinity.While the proposed rear dormer roof extension would not strictly adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, 2013, given that it would not be set down appropriately from the ridge line, it would be appropriately set in from the sides of the roof slope and in from the eaves, and as such would appear as a proportionate addition to the host property. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. The proposed front extension would adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD.Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the separation distance between the proposed development and neighbouring properties, and that the proposal would meet the 45-degree test in relation to the closest habitable windows of neighbouring properties in plan view, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light.While new openings are proposed to the side elevations at first and second floors of the proposed development, to mitigate against any potential loss of privacy/overlooking, in the event of an approval officers consider it appropriate to impose a condition to ensure that the openings are obscure-glazed and non-opening below 1.7m above finished floor levels.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: Whilst the proposal would include the conversion of the existing garage into habitable space, given that the internal dimensions of the existing garage would not conform to modern internal dimensions as recommended by the Sustainable Transport SPD, 2013, officers consider that the proposal would not result in the loss of off-street parking. The hard standing to the front of the property would accommodate 2 car parking spaces. Despite this level of provision exceeding the maximum standards set out in the London Plan, 2021, as this would reflect the existing situation, this matter would not warrant grounds for refusal.London Plan policy T5 requires all development to include provision for cycle parking. While the proposal would include the loss of the existing garage, the proposal would include a cycle store on site which is acceptable.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Site DescriptionThe site comprises a linked residential dwelling located on the southern side of Lingfield Avenue.It is not subject to any particular policy designations or environmental constraints.Consultation10 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. ProposalThe proposal relates to the replacement of the flat roof of the existing side extension with a pitched roof.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers acknowledge that the proposed alteration to the roof would be clearly visible within the streetscene. Whilst its relationship with the hip to gable roof extension achieved under application 21/02977/CEU would not be ideal, the form of the proposed roof in this case would be similar to alterations made to the neighbouring property, No. 50 Lingfield Avenue and would be finished in in-keeping materials and therefore would not have an unacceptable adverse impact on the streetscene or the character and appearance of the immediate surrounding area. Therefore, overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the proportionate and subordinate nature of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling located to the south of Ripon Gardens, Chessington. ProposalApplication under Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 to vary Condition 6 (C02 Emissions/Water Consumption) of Planning Permission ref: 20/03084/FUL (Retrospective planning application for conversion of existing dwelling into 2no. three-bedroom dwellings including conversion of existing garage into habitable space with single storey extensions to front and rear) dated 23/06/2021.Consultations 25 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposal and no representations were received.Thame Water: No response receivedRBK Pollution Control Team: No commentsPlanning History21/03826/CLC - Details required for Conditions 7 (Waste and Recycling) and 8 (Cycle Parking) of planning permission 20/03084/FUL (Retrospective planning application for conversion of existing dwelling into 2no. three-bedroom dwellings including conversion of existing garage into habitable space with single storey extensions to front and rear). Granted 26.01.2022.20/03084/FUL - Retrospective planning application for conversion of existing dwelling into 2no. three-bedroom dwellings including conversion of existing garage into habitable space with single storey extensions to front and rear. Granted - 23.06.2021AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:-	Sustainability SustainabilityPolicy DM 1 of the Council's Core Strategy (2012) sets sustainability and carbon reduction targets, albeit these have been superseded by Building Regulations. The following condition 6 was applied to planning permission 20/03084/FUL.Within three months of the date of this permission, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. Once approved, any measures necessary to meet the targets shall be maintained throughout the lifetime of the development.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012. The applicant has provided a statement arguing that:-	CO2 emissions are not relevant to a conversion which is subject to Part L 1B of the Building regulations, not Part L1A for new build development. The SAP software for Part L1B compliance has no facility to calculate CO2 emissions. Further, Part L1B of the Building Regulations contains no CO2 emissions reduction target or requirements.-	The reduction in water consumption is taken from Part G of the Building Regulations and again is only intended for new building dwellings. To reduce existing dwellings to a water consumption of 105 lp/d is going to require renewing existing fittings and is now what Part G was introduced for.It is accepted that this is a retrospective application for the conversion of an existing building, with only minor additional extensions, and that the CO2 reductions requirements set out in Condition 6 (and DM1 of the Core Strategy) do not apply to such developments. However, the water efficiency requirements remain valid and the applicant has agreed to retain the condition, removing only those parts that relate to CO2 reductions.ConclusionOverall, the variation of condition 6 of planning permission 20/03084/FUL is accepted and the proposal is not in conflict with Policy DM1 of the Core Strategy (2012).

Consultations26no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. 4no. representations, three objecting on the basis of car parking impacts resulting from the proposed development as well as proposed housing mix and amenity space and 1no. representation which is neutral in its content.RBK Highways and Transportation TeamNo response received.RBK Waste and Recycling TeamNo response received.RBK Policy TeamNo response received.RBK Environmental Health OfficerNo objection, subject to imposition of condition restricting construction hours.Planning HistoryApplication reference: 21/02623/FUL (310 and 312 Ewell Road) - Erection of rear extension to first and second floor of 312 Ewell Road and roof extension to 310 and 312 Ewell Road to form 3no. self-contained residential units with associated cycle storage and refuse/recycling store. Refused planning permission, dated 8 November 2021.Application reference: 21/02751/FUL - Erection of two-storey rear extension to first and second floors to create 2no. two-bedroom self-contained flats with associated amenity space, refuse/recycling facilities and cycle storage. Refused planning permission, dated 8 November 2021.Application reference: 19/01518/ADV - Display of 1x externally illuminated fascia sign and 1x non-illuminated projecting sign. Granted advert consent, 6 August 2019.ProposalThis application seeks full planning permission for the erection of two storey rear extension to first and second floors to create 2no. two-bedroom self-contained flats with associated amenity space, refuse/recycling facilities and cycle storage. Site and SurroundingsThe site is located on the southern side of Ewell Road. It comprises of a three-storey building which forms part of a terrace, near to the junction of Ewell Road with Douglas Road. The first and second floor are in residential use.The site forms part of the Ewell Road South Local Centre and the surrounding area is mixed in character comprising commercial and residential uses.The site is not located within a Conservation Area or a Local Area of Special Character and the building is not listed. The site is not located within a Flood Risk Zone.Planning ConsiderationsThe key planning considerations in this case are as follows:- The Principle of the Development;- Housing Mix;- The Standard of Accommodation;- The Character and Appearance of the Area;- The Amenities of Neighbouring Occupiers;- Transportation;- Refuse and Recycling; - SustainabilityPrinciple of DevelopmentPolicy CS10 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy, 2012 sets out the Borough's housing targets as defined by the London Plan, 2011.  Policy H1 (Increasing Housing Supply) of the London Plan (2021) sets ten-year targets for net housing completions that each local planning authority should plan for. Table 4.1 sets out the 10 year targets for net housing completions in each London Borough from 2019/20 - 2028/29). The requirement for Kingston is to deliver 9,640 homes in this 10 year period, which would equate to 964 net completions per annum.As there is no 5-year housing land supply, paragraph 11 of the NPPF indicates that planning permission should be granted unless (i) the application of policies in this Framework that protect areas or assets of particular importance provides a clear reason for refusing the development proposed; or (ii) any adverse impacts of doing so significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits, when assessed against policies in this Framework taken as a whole.  These considerations should be given considerable weight in the assessment of any forthcoming planning application.Whilst it is recognised that the Council does not have an up-to-date supply of housing sites, the benefits of the proposed development would need to be weighed against any significant adverse impacts, as required by paragraph 11 of the NPPF. Therefore, the 'tilted balance' as set out in paragraph 11 of the NPPF is engaged. Please refer to the last section of this report for the planning balance assessment.The site is in an established residential area and its use for residential purposes is well established. The principle of creating 2no. new residential units within an established residential area is acceptable, subject to compliance with Development Plan policies.Housing MixPolicy DM13 of the Council's Core Strategy states that housing developments should incorporate a mix of unit sizes and provide a minimum of 30% of dwellings as 3 or more bedroom units, unless it can be robustly demonstrated that this would be unsuitable or unviable.The proposal submitted in this application remains unchanged from that as previously refused, in that two 2-bed units are proposed. The proposed unit mix would be contrary to Policy DM13 of the Council's Core Strategy.Supporting justification has been provided to demonstrate that it is not possible to accommodate a 3-bed unit in the accommodation mix and that to meet the required minimum floorspace standards, this would require further extensions which would be harmful to the external rear elevation and negatively impact upon neighbouring amenity. Officers give this moderate weighting against the proposals.As the Council is in 'tilted balance', the conflict with Policy DM13 would need to be balanced by the overall economic, environmental and social benefits of the development. The final section of this report covers the planning balance assessment.Standard of AccommodationParagraph 130 of the NPPF 2021 states that planning decisions should ensure that developments will create places that are safe, inclusive and accessible and which promote health and well-being, with a high standard of amenity for existing and future users.Policy D6 of the London Plan, 2021 sets out the standards for new housing within London, in terms of overall gross internal area ("GIA"), built-in storage space, bedroom sizes and ceiling heights. Housing development should be of high quality design and provide adequately-sized rooms, with comfortable and functional layouts which are fit for purpose and meet the needs of Londoners without differentiating between tenures. Policy DM13 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 states that the Council will expect proposals for new residential development to demonstrate that the scheme has been designed to provide adequate internal space appropriate to the intended number of occupants. GIAThe nationally described space standard provides overall gross internal area ("GIA") requirements for various sizes of dwelling. The proposals show the following unit sizes and floor areas:-	Unit 1: 2-bed, 3-person flat. Proposed 63.7sqm GIA.-	Unit 2: 2-bed, 3-person flat. Proposed 61.0sqm GIA.According to the standards, dwellings of these sizes should have the following minimum floor area:-	2-bed, 3-person flat. Minimum GIA of 61sqm.Both of the proposed dwellings would either meet or exceed the minimum space standards.Built-In StorageThe standard also provides requirements for built-in storage space. The corresponding minimum standards for storage are set at 2.0sqm. The proposed dwellings would meet these requirements.BedroomsIn order to provide one bed space, a single bedroom should have a floor area of at least 7.5sqm and be at least 2.15m wide and in order to provide two bed spaces, a double (or twin) bedroom should have a floor area of at least 11.5sqm.One double (or twin) bedroom should be at least 2.75m wide, with every other such bedroom being at least 2.55m wide. The proposed bedrooms would be compliant with these space standards. Ceiling HeightsAny dwelling should also have a floor to ceiling height of at least 2.5m across 75% of its floor area, in recognition of the fact that ceiling heights are an important element in the design of a dwelling in the unique circumstances of London.Higher ceilings can help to offset issues associated with London's distinct higher densities and the effects of climate change by positively impacting on how spacious, light and comfortable the dwelling is. They can also improve the amount and quality of natural light and ventilation, and provide flexibility in the use of a room.The proposed dwellings would have a floor to ceiling heights of 2.5m or more throughout the first, second floors. This would be in compliance with standards set out in Policy D6 of the London Plan, 2021.Aspect, Outlook, Lighting and VentilationPolicy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy requires that developments have regard to the amenities of occupants in terms of outlook.Standard 29 of the Mayor's Housing SPG 2016 states that developments should minimise the number of single aspect dwellings. Single aspect dwellings that are north facing, or exposed to noise levels above which significant adverse effects on health and quality of life occur, or which contain three or more bedrooms should be avoided.The subtext to Policy D6 of the London Plan, 2021 goes onto say that dual aspect dwellings with opening windows on at least two sides have many inherent benefits. These include better daylight, a greater chance of direct sunlight for longer periods, natural cross ventilation and a greater capacity to address overheating, mitigating pollution, offering a choice of views, access to a quiet side of the building, greater flexibility in the use of rooms, and more potential for future adaptability by altering the use of rooms. While a bin store is shown on the proposed rear elevation, it is unclear whether there is sufficient space for the proposed store given the commercial use of this part of the site.Planning Balance/ConclusionThe proposal would provide a net increase of 2 studio flats on site and would increase an existing 1 bedroom flat into a 2 bedroom flat; this would make a positive, albeit modest, contribution toward meeting the Council's housing targets.However the proposed studios and extended flat would fail to provide a good standard of accommodation, it has not been demonstrated that the proposed flats would not prejudice the ongoing development of neighbouring businesses, the proposed unit mix would not contribute towards meeting the identified need for 3 or more bedroom units, it has not been demonstrated that on-site secure cycle parking and waste storage could be accommodated for the proposed studios.Overall, it is considered that the adverse impacts identified above would significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits of the scheme. It is therefore recommended that planning permission is refused.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey detached dwellinghouse located on Henley Drive. The site is subject to a blanket Tree Protection Order, as well as situated within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. Consultations5 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.Trees and Woodland - No comments. Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer - The proposed gates/railing would not impair existing visibility splays. The replacement gates are indicated as opening inwards so as not to obstruct the public highway and no changes are proposed to the existing vehicle crossover.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on heritage assets. The impact of the development on highways. The impact of the development on TPO trees. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the erection of a 2 metre high fence and gate to the front boundary of the property. Whilst uncommon along Henley Drive, some properties do already benefit from a high walls and gated entrances on the front boundary. As such the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them. Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements. Paragraph 203 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Officers Comments: The Kingston Hill/ Coombe Hill SASC constitutes a non-designated heritage asset. The significance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character can be summarised as an area of exceptionally high quality landscape with important views both within and beyond the Borough. Officers consider that the proposed development would not have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area. Subsequently officers consider that the proposed development would not harm the cultural significance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officers Comments: Consideration has been given to ensure the proposed gates and railing would not impair existing visibility splays. Additionally the proposed gates would open inwards so as not to obstruct the public highway. As such, Officers consider that the proposed development would not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy G7 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. If planning permission is granted that necessitates the removal of trees, there should be adequate replacement. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by TPOs are not adversely affected.Officers Comments: The application site is subject to a blanket TPO area. However, Officers consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect trees on site. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.10 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 objection has been received relating to:Loss of lightExcessive height or bulk of buildingsPrivacy The concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and, - The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note that the current application would propose a single storey rear extension of similar dimensions to previously refused app 21/01540/HOU. Given that the proposed rear extension would extend to meet the existing rear outbuilding, the depth of the proposed extension would not meet the requirements set out in the Residential Design SPD. However, given that the height of the proposed extension has been reduced and that the roof form would appear more in keeping with the original dwelling, officers consider that the proposed extension would appear a more proportionate addition to the host property and would not detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: While the proposal would sit on a raised platform, the proposed development would pass the 45-degree plan test in relation to the closest habitable windows of the neighbouring properties. As such, the proposed development is considered not to adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Officers note that a raised patio forms part of the proposals which would abut the shared boundary with No. 91 Brockenhurst Avenue. This could result in loss of privacy and overlooking, however, it is considered that this issue could be resolved by appropriate boundary fencing and enforced via condition in the event of an approval.  Subject to the satisfaction of a boundary condition, the proposed development is considered not to adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: While the proposal would include the conversion of the existing garage into habitable space, given that the internal dimensions of the existing garage would not conform to modern internal dimensions as recommended by the Sustainable Transport SPD, officers consider that the proposal would not result in the loss of on-site parking. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

would be set down from the ridge of the original roofslope, however it would have a flat roof which would not conform to the guidelines set out in the Residential Design SPD, and as such would not
